dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eLoaded plugin\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e will load \u003ccode\u003eproxy.http.proxy.HttpProxyPlugin\u003c/code\u003e by default\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAs name suggests, this core plugin adds \u003ccode\u003ehttp(s)\u003c/code\u003e proxy server capabilities to \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e instance\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eStarted N threadless workers\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBy default, \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e will start as many worker processes as there are CPU cores on the machine\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse \u003ccode\u003e--num-workers\u003c/code\u003e flag to customize number of worker processes\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSee \u003ca href=\"#threads-vs-threadless\"\u003eThreads vs Threadless\u003c/a\u003e to understand how to control execution mode\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eStarted N acceptors\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBy default, \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e will start as many acceptor processes as there are CPU cores on the machine\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse \u003ccode\u003e--num-acceptors\u003c/code\u003e flag to customize number of acceptor processes\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSee \u003ca href=\"#high-level-architecture\"\u003eHigh Level Architecture\u003c/a\u003e to understand relationship between acceptors and workers\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eStarted server on ::1:8899\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBy default, \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e listens on IPv6 \u003ccode\u003e::1\u003c/code\u003e, which is equivalent of IPv4 \u003ccode\u003e127.0.0.1\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIf you want to access \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e from external host, use \u003ccode\u003e--hostname ::\u003c/code\u003e or \u003ccode\u003e--hostname 0.0.0.0\u003c/code\u003e or bind to any other interface available on your machine.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSee \u003ca href=\"#customnetworkinterface\"\u003eCustomNetworkInterface\u003c/a\u003e for how to customize \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e \u003cem\u003epublic IP seen by upstream servers\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ePort 8899\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse \u003ccode\u003e--port\u003c/code\u003e flag to customize default TCP port.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv Then we reconstruct the response using custom hard-coded chunks, ignoring original chunks received from upstream server.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eStart \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ proxy \\\n    --plugins proxy.plugin.ModifyChunkResponsePlugin\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eproxy \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --plugins proxy.plugin.ModifyChunkResponsePlugin\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eVerify using \u003ccode\u003ecurl -v -x localhost:8899 http://httpbin.org/stream/5\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"... [redacted] ...\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003emodify\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003echunk\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003eresponse\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003eplugin\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e* Connection #0 to host localhost left intact\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e* Closing connection 0\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eModify \u003ccode\u003eModifyChunkResponsePlugin\u003c/code\u003e to your taste. Example, instead of sending hard-coded chunks, parse and modify the original \u003ccode\u003eJSON\u003c/code\u003e chunks received from the upstream server.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eCloudflareDnsResolverPlugin\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-cloudflarednsresolverplugin\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: CloudflareDnsResolverPlugin\" href=\"#cloudflarednsresolverplugin\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis plugin uses \u003ccode\u003eCloudflare\u003c/code\u003e hosted \u003ccode\u003eDNS-over-HTTPS\u003c/code\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://developers.cloudflare.com/1.1.1.1/encrypted-dns/dns-over-https/make-api-requests/dns-json\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAPI\u003c/a\u003e (json).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eDoH\u003c/code\u003e mandates a HTTP2 compliant client. Unfortunately \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e\ndoes not provide that yet, so we use a dependency. Install it:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ pip install \u0026quot;httpx[http2]\u0026quot;\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003epip install \u003cspan class=\"pl-s\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003ehttpx[http2]\u003cspan class=\"pl-pds\"\u003e\"\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNow start \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ proxy \\\n    --plugins proxy.plugin.CloudflareDnsResolverPlugin\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eproxy \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --plugins proxy.plugin.CloudflareDnsResolverPlugin\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBy default, \u003ccode\u003eCloudflareDnsResolverPlugin\u003c/code\u003e runs in \u003ccode\u003esecurity\u003c/code\u003e mode and provides malware protection.\nUse \u003ccode\u003e--cloudflare-dns-mode family\u003c/code\u003e to also enable adult content protection too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" the order in which plugins are passed\non the command line.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ePlugins are called in the same order as they are passed. Example,\nsay we are using both \u003ccode\u003eFilterByUpstreamHostPlugin\u003c/code\u003e and\n\u003ccode\u003eRedirectToCustomServerPlugin\u003c/code\u003e. Idea is to drop all incoming \u003ccode\u003ehttp\u003c/code\u003e\nrequests for \u003ccode\u003efacebook.com\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ewww.facebook.com\u003c/code\u003e and redirect other\n\u003ccode\u003ehttp\u003c/code\u003e requests to our inbuilt web server.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHence, in this scenario it is important to use\n\u003ccode\u003eFilterByUpstreamHostPlugin\u003c/code\u003e before \u003ccode\u003eRedirectToCustomServerPlugin\u003c/code\u003e.\nIf we enable \u003ccode\u003eRedirectToCustomServerPlugin\u003c/code\u003e before \u003ccode\u003eFilterByUpstreamHostPlugin\u003c/code\u003e,\n\u003ccode\u003efacebook\u003c/code\u003e requests will also get redirected to inbuilt web server,\ninstead of being dropped.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch1 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eBy default, \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e uses \u003ccode\u003ehttp\u003c/code\u003e protocol for communication with clients e.g. \u003ccode\u003ecurl\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003ebrowser\u003c/code\u003e. For enabling end-to-end encrypting using \u003ccode\u003etls\u003c/code\u003e / \u003ccode\u003ehttps\u003c/code\u003e first generate certificates. \u003cstrong\u003eCheckout\u003c/strong\u003e the repository and run:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"make https-certificates\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003emake https-certificates\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eStart \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ proxy \\\n    --cert-file https-cert.pem \\\n    --key-file https-key.pem\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eproxy https-key.pem\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eVerify using \u003ccode\u003ecurl -x https://localhost:8899 --proxy-cacert https-cert.pem to avoid passing \u003ccode\u003e--proxy-cacert\u003c/code\u003e flag, also consider signing generated SSL certificates. Example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFirst, generate CA certificates:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"make ca-certificates\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003emake ca-certificates\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThen, sign SSL certificate:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"make sign-https-certificates\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003emake sign-https-certificates\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNow restart the server with \u003ccode\u003e--cert-file https-signed-cert.pem\u003c/code\u003e flag. Note that you must also trust generated \u003ccode\u003eca-cert.pem\u003c/code\u003e in your system keychain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch1 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eTLS Interception\u003c/h1\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-tls-interception\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: TLS Interception\" href=\"#tls-interception\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBy default, \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e will not decrypt \u003ccode\u003ehttps\u003c/code\u003e traffic between client and server.\nTo enable TLS interception first generate root CA certificates:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ make ca-certificates\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emake ca-certificates\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eLets also enable \u003ccode\u003eCacheResponsePlugin\u003c/code\u003e so that we can verify decrypted\nresponse from the server. Start \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e as:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ proxy \\\n    --plugins proxy.plugin.CacheResponsesPlugin \\\n    --ca-key-file ca-key.pem \\\n    --ca-cert-file ca-cert.pem \\\n    --ca-signing-key-file ca-signing-key.pem\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eproxy \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --plugins proxy.plugin.CacheResponsesPlugin \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --ca-key-file ca-key.pem \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --ca-cert-file ca-cert.pem \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --ca-signing-key-file ca-signing-key.pem\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/abhinavsingh/proxy.py#user-content-flags\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://camo.githubusercontent.com/ae622aa0292fe3312939156e3246f55b973fc4c60c0ab0baad766760a509f8fb/68747470733a2f2f696d672e736869656c64732e696f2f7374617469632f76313f6c6162656c3d4d61634f53266d6573736167653d6e6f746526636f6c6f723d79656c6c6f77\" alt=\"NOTE\" data-canonical-src=\"https://img.shields.io/static/v1?label=MacOS\u0026amp;message=note\u0026amp;color=yellow\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e Also provide explicit CA bundle path needed for validation of peer certificates. See \u003ccode\u003e--ca-file\u003c/code\u003e flag.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eVerify TLS interception using \u003ccode\u003ecurl\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ curl -v -x localhost:8899 --cacert ca-cert.pem https://httpbin.org/get\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ecurl -v -x localhost:8899 --cacert ca-cert.pem https://httpbin.org/get\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"*  issuer: C=US; ST=CA; L=SanFrancisco; O=proxy.py; OU=CA; CN=Proxy PY CA; emailAddress=proxyca@mailserver.com\n*  SSL certificate verify ok.\n\u0026gt; GET /get HTTP/1.1\n... [redacted] ...\n\u0026lt; Connection: keep-alive\n\u0026lt;\n{\n  \u0026quot;args\u0026quot;: {},\n  \u0026quot;headers\u0026quot;: {\n    \u0026quot;Accept\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;*/*\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;Host\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;httpbin.org\u0026quot;,\n    \u0026quot;User-Agent\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;curl/7.54.0\u0026quot;\n  },\n  \u0026quot;origin\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;1.2.3.4, 5.6.7.8\u0026quot;,\n  \u0026quot;url\u0026quot;: \u0026quot;https://httpbin.org/get\u0026quot;\n}\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*  issuer: C=US; ST=CA; L=SanFrancisco; O=proxy.py; OU=CA; CN=Proxy PY CA; emailAddress=proxyca@mailserver.com\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*  SSL certificate verify ok.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u0026gt; \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003eGET /get HTTP/1.1\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e... Get path to the cache\nfile from \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e logs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e❯ cat /path/to/your/tmp/directory/httpbin.org-1569452863.924174.txt\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"HTTP/1.1 200 OK\nAccess-Control-Allow-Credentials: true\nAccess-Control-Allow-Origin: *\nContent-Type: application/json\nDate: Wed, 25 Sep 2019 23:07:05 GMT\nReferrer-Policy: no-referrer-when-downgrade\nServer: nginx\nX-Content-Type-Options: nosniff\nX-Frame-Options: DENY\nX-XSS-Protection: 1; If you remove CA flags, encrypted data will be found in the\ncached file instead of plain text.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eNow use CA flags with other\n\u003ca href=\"#plugin-examples\"\u003eplugin examples\u003c/a\u003e to see them work with \u003ccode\u003ehttps\u003c/code\u003e traffic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eTLS Interception With Docker\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-tls-interception-with-docker\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: TLS Interception With Docker\" href=\"#tls-interception-with-docker\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eImportant notes about TLS Interception with Docker container:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSince \u003ccode\u003ev2.2.0\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e docker container also ships with \u003ccode\u003eopenssl\u003c/code\u003e. This allows \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e\nto generate certificates on the fly for TLS Interception.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor security reasons, \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e docker container does not ship with\nCA certificates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHere is how to start a \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e docker container\nwith TLS Interception:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eGenerate CA certificates on host computer\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ make ca-certificates\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emake ca-certificates\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eCopy all generated certificates into a separate directory. We'll later mount this directory into our docker container\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ mkdir /tmp/ca-certificates\n❯ cp ca-cert.pem ca-key.pem ca-signing-key.pem /tmp/ca-certificates\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emkdir /tmp/ca-certificates\u003c/span\u003e\n❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ecp ca-cert.pem ca-key.pem ca-signing-key.pem /tmp/ca-certificates\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eStart docker container\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ docker run -it --rm \\\n    -v /tmp/ca-certificates:/tmp/ca-certificates \\\n    -p 8899:8899 \\\n    abhinavsingh/proxy.py:latest \\\n    --hostname 0.0.0.0 \\\n    --plugins proxy.plugin.CacheResponsesPlugin \\\n    --ca-key-file /tmp/ca-certificates/ca-key.pem \\\n    --ca-cert-file /tmp/ca-certificates/ca-cert.pem \\\n    --ca-signing-key /tmp/ca-certificates/ca-signing-key.pem\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003edocker run -it --rm \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    -v /tmp/ca-certificates:/tmp/ca-certificates \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    -p 8899:8899 \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    abhinavsingh/proxy.py:latest \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --hostname 0.0.0.0 \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --plugins proxy.plugin.CacheResponsesPlugin \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --ca-key-file /tmp/ca-certificates/ca-key.pem \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --ca-cert-file /tmp/ca-certificates/ca-cert.pem \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --ca-signing-key /tmp/ca-certificates/ca-signing-key.pem\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e-v /tmp/ca-certificates:/tmp/ca-certificates\u003c/code\u003e flag mounts our CA certificate directory in container environment\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e--plugins proxy.plugin.CacheResponsesPlugin\u003c/code\u003e enables \u003ccode\u003eCacheResponsesPlugin\u003c/code\u003e so that we can inspect intercepted traffic\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003e--ca-*\u003c/code\u003e flags enable TLS Interception.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFrom another terminal, try TLS Interception using \u003ccode\u003ecurl\u003c/code\u003e. You can omit \u003ccode\u003e--cacert\u003c/code\u003e flag if CA certificate is already trusted by the system.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"❯ curl -v \\\n    --cacert ca-cert.pem \\\n    -x 127.0.0.1:8899 \\\n    https://httpbin.org/get\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e❯ \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003ecurl -v \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    --cacert ca-cert.pem \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    -x 127.0.0.1:8899 \\\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e    https://httpbin.org/get\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eVerify \u003ccode\u003eissuer\u003c/code\u003e field from response headers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"* Server certificate:\n*  subject: CN=httpbin.org; C=NA; ST=Unavailable; L=Unavailable; O=Unavailable; OU=Unavailable\n*  start date: Jun 17 09:26:57 2020 GMT\n*  expire date: Jun 17 09:26:57 2022 GMT\n*  subjectAltName: host \u0026quot;httpbin.org\u0026quot; matched cert's \u0026quot;httpbin.org\u0026quot;\n*  issuer: CN=example.com\n*  SSL certificate verify ok.\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e* Server certificate:\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*  subject: CN=httpbin.org; C=NA; ST=Unavailable; L=Unavailable; O=Unavailable; OU=Unavailable\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*  start date: Jun 17 09:26:57 2020 GMT\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*  expire date: Jun 17 09:26:57 2022 GMT\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*  subjectAltName: host \"httpbin.org\" matched cert's \"httpbin.org\"\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*  issuer: CN=example.com\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e*  SSL certificate verify ok.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBack on docker terminal, copy response dump path logs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"...[redacted]... another terminal, \u003ccode\u003ecat\u003c/code\u003e the response dump:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" And hence, for your production grade applications, you \u003cem\u003eMUST\u003c/em\u003e integrate application CI/CD with \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e.  You must make sure that your application builds and passes its tests for every PR merge into the \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e upstream repo.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf your application repository is public, in certain scenarios, PR authors may send patch PRs for all dependents to maintain backward incompatibility and green CI/CD.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eCI/CD integration ensure your app continues to build with latest \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e code.  Depending upon where you host your code, use the strategy listed below:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eGitHub\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTBD\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eGoogle Cloud Build\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTBD\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAWS\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTBD\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAzure\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTBD\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOthers\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTBD\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAt some stage, we'll deprecate \u003ccode\u003emaster\u003c/code\u003e branch segregation and simply maintain a \u003ccode\u003edevelop\u003c/code\u003e branch.  As dependents can maintain stability via CI/CD integrations. Currently, it's hard for a production grade project to blindly depend upon \u003ccode\u003edevelop\u003c/code\u003e branch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eStable vs Develop\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-stable-vs-develop\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Stable vs Develop\" href=\"#stable-vs-develop\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003emaster\u003c/code\u003e branch contains latest \u003ccode\u003estable\u003c/code\u003e code and is available via \u003ccode\u003ePyPi\u003c/code\u003e repository and \u003ccode\u003eDocker\u003c/code\u003e containers via \u003ccode\u003edocker.io\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003eghcr.io\u003c/code\u003e registries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIssues reported for \u003ccode\u003estable\u003c/code\u003e releases are considered with top-priority.  However, currently we don't back port fixes into older releases.  Example, if you reported an issue in \u003ccode\u003ev2.3.1\u003c/code\u003e, but current \u003ccode\u003emaster\u003c/code\u003e branch now contains \u003ccode\u003ev2.4.0rc1\u003c/code\u003e.  Then, the fix will land in \u003ccode\u003ev2.4.0rc2\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003edevelop\u003c/code\u003e branch contains cutting edge changes\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDevelopment branch is kept stable \u003cem\u003e(most of the times)\u003c/em\u003e. \u003cstrong\u003eBut\u003c/strong\u003e, if you want \u003cem\u003e100% reliability\u003c/em\u003e and serving users in \u003cem\u003eproduction environment\u003c/em\u003e, ALWAYS use the stable version.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eRelease Schedule\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-release-schedule\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Release Schedule\" href=\"#release-schedule\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA \u003ccode\u003evX.Y.ZrcN\u003c/code\u003e pull request is created once a month which merges \u003ccode\u003edevelop\u003c/code\u003e → \u003ccode\u003emaster\u003c/code\u003e.  Find below how code flows from a pull request to the next stable release.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDevelopment release is deployed from \u003ccode\u003edevelop\u003c/code\u003e → \u003ccode\u003etest.pypi.org\u003c/code\u003e after every pull request merge\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAlpha release is deployed from \u003ccode\u003edevelop\u003c/code\u003e → \u003ccode\u003epypi.org\u003c/code\u003e \u003cstrong\u003ebefore\u003c/strong\u003e merging the \u003ccode\u003evX.Y.Z.rcN\u003c/code\u003e pull request from \u003ccode\u003edevelop\u003c/code\u003e → \u003ccode\u003emaster\u003c/code\u003e branch.  There can be multiple alpha releases made before merging the \u003ccode\u003erc\u003c/code\u003e pull request\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBeta release is deployed from \u003ccode\u003emaster\u003c/code\u003e → \u003ccode\u003epypi.org\u003c/code\u003e.  Beta releases are made in preparation of \u003ccode\u003erc\u003c/code\u003e releases and can be skipped if unnecessary\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRelease candidate is deployed from \u003ccode\u003emaster\u003c/code\u003e → \u003ccode\u003epypi.org\u003c/code\u003e.  Release candidates are always made available before final stable release\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eStable release is deployed from \u003ccode\u003emaster\u003c/code\u003e → \u003ccode\u003epypi.org\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 on \u003ccode\u003emac\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003elinux\u003c/code\u003e environments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e threadless execution has been reported safe on these environments by our users. If you are running into trouble, fallback to threaded mode using \u003ccode\u003e--threaded\u003c/code\u003e flag.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor \u003ccode\u003ewindows\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003ePython \u0026lt; 3.8\u003c/code\u003e, you can still try out threadless mode by starting \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e with \u003ccode\u003e--threadless\u003c/code\u003e flag.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf threadless works for you, consider sending a PR by editing \u003ccode\u003e_env_threadless_compliant\u003c/code\u003e method in the \u003ccode\u003eproxy/common/constants.py\u003c/code\u003e file.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eThreadless Remote vs Local execution mode\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-threadless-remote-vs-local-execution-mode\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Threadless Remote vs Local execution mode\" href=\"#threadless-remote-vs-local-execution-mode\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOriginal threadless implementation used \u003ccode\u003eremote\u003c/code\u003e execution mode.  This is also depicted under \u003ca href=\"#high-level-architecture\"\u003eHigh level architecture\u003c/a\u003e as ASCII art.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eUnder \u003ccode\u003eremote\u003c/code\u003e execution mode, acceptors delegate incoming client connection processing to a remote worker process.  By default, acceptors delegate connections in round-robin fashion.  Worker processing the request may or may not be running on the same CPU core as the acceptor.  This architecture scales well for high throughput, but results in spawning two process per CPU core.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eExample, if there are N-CPUs on the machine, by default, N acceptors and N worker processes are started.  You can tune number of processes using \u003ccode\u003e--num-acceptors\u003c/code\u003e and \u003ccode\u003e--num-workers\u003c/code\u003e flag.  You might want more workers than acceptors or vice versa depending upon your use case.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn v2.4.x, \u003ccode\u003elocal\u003c/code\u003e execution mode was added, mainly to reduce number of processes spawned by default.  This model serves well for day-to-day single user use cases and for developer testing scenarios.  Under \u003ccode\u003elocal\u003c/code\u003e execution mode, acceptors delegate client connections to a companion thread, instead of a remote process.  \u003ccode\u003elocal\u003c/code\u003e execution mode ensure CPU affinity, unlike in the \u003ccode\u003eremote\u003c/code\u003e mode where acceptor and worker might be running on different CPU cores.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e--local-executor 1\u003c/code\u003e was made default in v2.4.x series.  Under \u003ccode\u003elocal\u003c/code\u003e execution mode, \u003ccode\u003e--num-workers\u003c/code\u003e flag has no effect, as no remote workers are started.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo use \u003ccode\u003eremote\u003c/code\u003e execution mode, use \u003ccode\u003e--local-executor 0\u003c/code\u003e flag.  Then use \u003ccode\u003e--num-workers\u003c/code\u003e to tune number of worker processes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eSyntaxError: invalid syntax\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-syntaxerror-invalid-syntax\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: SyntaxError: invalid syntax\" href=\"#syntaxerror-invalid-syntax\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e is strictly typed and uses Python \u003ccode\u003etyping\u003c/code\u003e annotations. Example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-python notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"\u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; my_strings : List[str] = []\n\u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u0026gt; #############^^^^^^^^^#####\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e\u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003emy_strings\u003c/span\u003e : \u003cspan class=\"pl-v\"\u003eList\u003c/span\u003e[\u003cspan class=\"pl-s1\"\u003estr\u003c/span\u003e] \u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e=\u003c/span\u003e []\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e\u0026gt;\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e\u0026gt;\u003c/span\u003e \u003cspan class=\"pl-c\"\u003e#############^^^^^^^^^#####\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHence a Python version that understands typing annotations is required.\nMake sure you are using \u003ccode\u003ePython 3.6+\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eVerify the version before running \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e❯ python --version\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAll \u003ccode\u003etyping\u003c/code\u003e annotations can be replaced with \u003ccode\u003ecomment-only\u003c/code\u003e annotations. -n\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake sure to adjust \u003ccode\u003e--backlog\u003c/code\u003e flag for higher concurrency.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp in access logs. It simply means\nthat an upstream server connection was never established i.e.\n\u003ccode\u003eupstream_host=None\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003eupstream_port=None\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere can be several reasons for no upstream connection,\nfew obvious ones include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eClient established a connection but never completed the request.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eA plugin returned a response prematurely, avoiding connection to upstream server.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eSome clients can throw \u003ccode\u003eTLSV1_ALERT_UNKNOWN_CA\u003c/code\u003e if they cannot verify the certificate of the server\nbecause it is signed by an unknown issuer CA.  Which is the case when we are doing TLS interception.\nThis can be for a variety of reasons e.g. certificate pinning etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAnother exception you might see is \u003ccode\u003eCERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED\u003c/code\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"2021-11-06 23:36:02,002 - pid:91033 [E] handler.handle_readables:293 - Exception while receiving from client connection \u0026lt;socket.socket fd=28, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=0, laddr=('127.0.0.1', 8899), raddr=('127.0.0.1', 51961)\u0026gt; with reason SSLCertVerificationError(1, '[SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: self signed certificate in certificate chain (_ssl.c:997)')\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  ...[redacted]...\n  ...[redacted]...\n  ...[redacted]...\nssl.SSLCertVerificationError: [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: self signed certificate in certificate chain (_ssl.c:997)\n...[redacted]... - CONNECT init.push.apple.com:443 - 0 bytes - 892.99 ms\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e2021-11-06 23:36:02,002 - pid:91033 [E] handler.handle_readables:293 - Exception while receiving from client connection \u0026lt;socket.socket fd=28, family=AddressFamily.AF_INET, type=SocketKind.SOCK_STREAM, proto=0, laddr=('127.0.0.1', 8899), raddr=('127.0.0.1', 51961)\u0026gt; with reason SSLCertVerificationError(1, '[SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: self signed certificate in certificate chain (_ssl.c:997)')\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003eTraceback (most recent call last):\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e  ...[redacted]...\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e  ...[redacted]...\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e  ...[redacted]...\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003essl.SSLCertVerificationError: [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: self signed certificate in certificate chain (_ssl.c:997)\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e...[redacted]... - CONNECT init.push.apple.com:443 - 0 bytes - 892.99 ms\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn future, we might support serving original HTTPS content for such clients while still\nperforming TLS interception in the background.  This will keep the clients happy without\nimpacting our ability to TLS intercept.  Unfortunately, this feature is currently not available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAnother example with \u003ccode\u003eSSLEOFError\u003c/code\u003e exception:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e         |      ||      ||      ||      ||      |\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e         +------++------++------++------++------+\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003cspan class=\"pl-c1\"\u003e                Threadless Worker Processes\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e is made with performance in mind.  By default, \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e\nwill try to utilize all available CPU cores to it for accepting new\nclient connections. This is achieved by starting \u003ccode\u003eAcceptorPool\u003c/code\u003e which\nlistens on configured server port. Then, \u003ccode\u003eAcceptorPool\u003c/code\u003e starts \u003ccode\u003eAcceptor\u003c/code\u003e\nprocesses (\u003ccode\u003e--num-acceptors\u003c/code\u003e) to accept incoming client connections.\nAlongside, if \u003ccode\u003e--threadless\u003c/code\u003e is enabled, \u003ccode\u003eThreadlessPool\u003c/code\u003e is setup\nwhich starts \u003ccode\u003eThreadless\u003c/code\u003e processes (\u003ccode\u003e--num-workers\u003c/code\u003e) to handle\nthe incoming client connections.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eEach \u003ccode\u003eAcceptor\u003c/code\u003e process delegates the accepted client connection\nto a threadless process via \u003ccode\u003eWork\u003c/code\u003e class.  Currently, \u003ccode\u003eHttpProtocolHandler\u003c/code\u003e\nis the default work class.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eHttpProtocolHandler\u003c/code\u003e simply assumes that incoming clients will follow\nHTTP specification.  Specific HTTP proxy and HTTP server implementations\nare written as plugins of \u003ccode\u003eHttpProtocolHandler\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSee documentation of \u003ccode\u003eHttpProtocolHandlerPlugin\u003c/code\u003e for available lifecycle hooks.\nUse \u003ccode\u003eHttpProtocolHandlerPlugin\u003c/code\u003e to add new features for http(s) clients. Example,\nSee \u003ccode\u003eHttpWebServerPlugin\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eEverything is a plugin\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-everything-is-a-plugin\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Everything is a plugin\" href=\"#everything-is-a-plugin\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWithin \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e everything is a plugin.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe enabled \u003ccode\u003eproxy server\u003c/code\u003e plugins using \u003ccode\u003e--plugins\u003c/code\u003e flag.\nProxy server \u003ccode\u003eHttpProxyPlugin\u003c/code\u003e is a plugin of \u003ccode\u003eHttpProtocolHandler\u003c/code\u003e.\nFurther, Proxy server allows plugin through \u003ccode\u003eHttpProxyBasePlugin\u003c/code\u003e specification.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAll the proxy server \u003ca href=\"#plugin-examples\"\u003eplugin examples\u003c/a\u003e were implementing\n\u003ccode\u003eHttpProxyBasePlugin\u003c/code\u003e. See documentation of \u003ccode\u003eHttpProxyBasePlugin\u003c/code\u003e for available\nlifecycle hooks. Use \u003ccode\u003eHttpProxyBasePlugin\u003c/code\u003e to modify behavior of http(s) proxy protocol\nbetween client and upstream server. Example,\n\u003ca href=\"#filterbyupstreamhostplugin\"\u003eFilterByUpstreamHostPlugin\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe also enabled inbuilt \u003ccode\u003eweb server\u003c/code\u003e using \u003ccode\u003e--enable-web-server\u003c/code\u003e.\nWeb server \u003ccode\u003eHttpWebServerPlugin\u003c/code\u003e is a plugin of \u003ccode\u003eHttpProtocolHandler\u003c/code\u003e\nand implements \u003ccode\u003eHttpProtocolHandlerPlugin\u003c/code\u003e specification.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThere also is a \u003ccode\u003e--disable-http-proxy\u003c/code\u003e flag. It disables inbuilt proxy server.\nUse this flag with \u003ccode\u003e--enable-web-server\u003c/code\u003e flag to run \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e as a programmable\nhttp(s) server.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eManaging states for your stateless plugins\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-managing-states-for-your-stateless-plugins\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Managing states for your stateless plugins\" href=\"#managing-states-for-your-stateless-plugins\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ePlugin class instances are created per-request.  Most importantly,\nplugin instances are created within CPU core context where the request\nwas received.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor above reason, global variables in your plugins may work as expected.\nYour plugin code by design must be \u003cstrong\u003estateless\u003c/strong\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo manage global states, you have a couple of options:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake use of Python's \u003ca href=\"https://python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/library/multiprocessing.html#sharing-state-between-processes\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emultiprocessing safe data structures\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake use of \u003ccode\u003eproxy.py\u003c/code\u003e in-built \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/abhinavsingh/proxy.py/blob/develop/tutorial/eventing.ipynb\"\u003eeventing mechanism\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" processing chain.  Example, this additional\ncontext can also be dumped as part of access logs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo pass processing context, make use of plugin's \u003ccode\u003eon_access_log\u003c/code\u003e method.  See how \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/abhinavsingh/proxy.py/blob/develop/proxy/plugin/program_name.py\"\u003eProgram Name\u003c/a\u003e plugin modifies default \u003ccode\u003eclient_ip\u003c/code\u003e key in the context and updates it to detected program name.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAs a result, when we enable \u003ca href=\"#programnameplugin\"\u003eProgram Name Plugin\u003c/a\u003e, we see local client program name instead of IP address in the access logs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" how to run benchmarks locally.</p></li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Lightweight</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Uses only <code>~5-20 MB</code> RAM<ul dir="auto"><li>No memory leaks</li><li>Start once and forget, no restarts required</li></ul></li><li>Compressed containers size is only <code>~25 MB</code></li><li>No external dependency other than standard Python library</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Programmable</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Customize proxy behavior using <a href="#http-proxy-plugins">Proxy Server Plugins</a>. Example:<ul dir="auto"><li><code>--plugins proxy.plugin.ProxyPoolPlugin</code></li></ul></li><li>Enable builtin <a href="#http-web-server-plugins">Web Server</a>. Example:<ul dir="auto"><li><code>--enable-web-server --plugins proxy.plugin.WebServerPlugin</code></li></ul></li><li>Enable builtin <a href="#reverse-proxy-plugins">Reverse Proxy Server</a>. Example:<ul dir="auto"><li><code>--enable-reverse-proxy --plugins proxy.plugin.ReverseProxyPlugin</code></li></ul></li><li>Plugin API is currently in <em>development phase</em>. Expect breaking changes. See <a href="#deploying-proxypy-in-production">Deploying proxy.py in production</a> on how to ensure reliability across code changes.</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Can listen on multiple addresses and ports</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Use <code>--hostnames</code> flag to provide additional addresses</li><li>Use <code>--ports</code> flag to provide additional ports</li><li>Optionally, use <code>--port</code> flag to override default port <code>8899</code></li><li>Capable of serving multiple protocols over the same port</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Real-time Dashboard</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Optionally, enable <a href="#run-dashboard">proxy.py dashboard</a>.<ul dir="auto"><li>Use <code>--enable-dashboard</code></li><li>Then, visit <code>http://localhost:8899/dashboard</code></li></ul></li><li><a href="#inspect-traffic">Inspect, Monitor, Control and Configure</a> <code>proxy.py</code> at runtime</li><li><a href="#chrome-devtools-protocol">Chrome DevTools Protocol</a> support</li><li>Extend dashboard frontend using <code>typescript</code> based <a href="https://github.com/abhinavsingh/proxy.py/tree/develop/dashboard/src/plugins">plugins</a></li><li>Dashboard is currently in <em>development phase</em>  Expect breaking changes.</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Secure</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Enable end-to-end encryption between clients and <code>proxy.py</code></li><li>See <a href="#end-to-end-encryption">End-to-End Encryption</a></li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Private</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Protection against DNS based traffic blockers</li><li>Browse with malware and adult content protection enabled</li><li>See <a href="#cloudflarednsresolverplugin">DNS-over-HTTPS</a></li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Man-In-The-Middle</p><ul dir="auto"><li>Can decrypt TLS traffic between clients and upstream servers</li><li>See <a href="#tls-interception">TLS Interception</a></li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Supported http protocols for proxy requests</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>http(s)</code><ul dir="auto"><li><code>http1</code></li><li><code>http1.1</code> with pipeline</li></ul></li><li><code>http2</code></li><li><code>websockets</code></li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Support for <code>HAProxy Protocol</code></p><ul dir="auto"><li>See <code>--enable-proxy-protocol</code> flag</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Static file server support</p><ul dir="auto"><li>See <code>--enable-static-server</code> and <code>--static-server-dir</code> flags</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Optimized for large file uploads and downloads</p><ul dir="auto"><li>See <code>--client-recvbuf-size</code>, <code>--server-recvbuf-size</code>, <code>--max-sendbuf-size</code> flags</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto"><code>IPv4</code> and <code>IPv6</code> support</p><ul dir="auto"><li>See <code>--hostname</code> flag</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Unix domain socket support</p><ul dir="auto"><li>See <code>--unix-socket-path</code> flag</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">Basic authentication support</p><ul dir="auto"><li>See <code>--basic-auth</code> flag</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto">PAC (Proxy Auto-configuration) support</p><ul dir="auto"><li>See 127.0.0.1:8899</span></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Understanding logs</h3><a id="user-content-understanding-logs" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Understanding logs" href="#understanding-logs"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Things to notice from above logs:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto"><code>Loaded plugin</code></p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>proxy.py</code> will load <code>proxy.http.proxy.HttpProxyPlugin</code> by default</li><li>As name suggests, this core plugin adds <code>http(s)</code> proxy server capabilities to <code>proxy.py</code> instance</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto"><code>Started N threadless workers</code></p><ul dir="auto"><li>By default, <code>proxy.py</code> will start as many worker processes as there are CPU cores on the machine</li><li>Use <code>--num-workers</code> flag to customize number of worker processes</li><li>See <a href="#threads-vs-threadless">Threads vs Threadless</a> to understand how to control execution mode</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto"><code>Started N acceptors</code></p><ul dir="auto"><li>By default, <code>proxy.py</code> will start as many acceptor processes as there are CPU cores on the machine</li><li>Use <code>--num-acceptors</code> flag to customize number of acceptor processes</li><li>See <a href="#high-level-architecture">High Level Architecture</a> to understand relationship between acceptors and workers</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto"><code>Started server on ::1:8899</code></p><ul dir="auto"><li>By default, <code>proxy.py</code> listens on IPv6 <code>::1</code>, which is equivalent of IPv4 <code>127.0.0.1</code></li><li>If you want to access <code>proxy.py</code> from external host, use <code>--hostname ::</code> or <code>--hostname 0.0.0.0</code> or bind to any other interface available on your machine.</li><li>See <a href="#customnetworkinterface">CustomNetworkInterface</a> for how to customize <code>proxy.py</code> <em>public IP seen by upstream servers</em>.</li></ul></li><li><p dir="auto"><code>Port 8899</code></p><ul dir="auto"><li>Use <code>--port</code> flag to customize default TCP port.</li></ul></li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Enable DEBUG logging</h3><a id="user-content-enable-debug-logging" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Enable DEBUG logging" 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 <code>--log-level</code> for <code>proxy.py</code></p><p dir="auto">Lets start <code>proxy.py</code> with <code>DEBUG</code> level logging:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ proxy --log-level d...[redacted]... - Open file descriptor soft limit set to 1024...[redacted]... - Loaded plugin proxy.http_proxy.HttpProxyPlugin...[redacted]... - Started 8 workers...[redacted]... - Started server on ::1:8899"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">proxy --log-level d</span><span class="pl-c1">...[redacted]... - Open file descriptor soft limit set to 1024</span><span class="pl-c1">...[redacted]... - Loaded plugin proxy.http_proxy.HttpProxyPlugin</span><span class="pl-c1">...[redacted]... - Started 8 workers</span><span class="pl-c1">...[redacted]... - Started server on ::1:8899</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">You can use single letter to customize log level.  Example:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>d = DEBUG</code></li><li><code>i = INFO</code></li><li><code>w = WARNING</code></li><li><code>e = ERROR</code></li><li><code>c = CRITICAL</code></li></ul><p dir="auto">As we can see from the above logs, before starting up:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><code>proxy.py</code> tried to set open file limit <code>ulimit</code> on the system</li><li>Default value for <code>--open-file-limit</code> used is <code>1024</code></li><li><code>--open-file-limit</code> flag is a no-op on <code>Windows</code> operating systems</li></ul><p dir="auto">See <a href="#flags">flags</a> for full list of available configuration options.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">From command line using repo source</h2><a id="user-content-from-command-line-using-repo-source" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: From command line using repo source" href="#from-command-line-using-repo-source"><svg source code.</p><p dir="auto">To start <code>proxy.py</code> from source code follow these instructions:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><p dir="auto">Clone repo</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ git clone https://github.com/abhinavsingh/proxy.py.git❯ cd proxy.py"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">git clone https://github.com/abhinavsingh/proxy.py.git</span>❯ <span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-c1">cd</span> proxy.py</span></pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Create a Python 3 virtual env</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ python3 -m venv venv❯ source venv/bin/activate"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">python3 -m venv venv</span>❯ <span class="pl-s1"><span class="pl-c1">source</span> venv/bin/activate</span></pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Install deps</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ make lib-dep"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">make lib-dep</span></pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Generate <code>proxy/common/_scm_version.py</code></p><p dir="auto">NOTE: <em>Following step is not necessary for editable installs.</em></p><p dir="auto">This file writes SCM detected version to <code>proxy/common/_scm_version.py</code> file.</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ ./write-scm-version.sh"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">./write-scm-version.sh</span></pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Optionally, run tests</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ make"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">make</span></pre></div></li><li><p dir="auto">Run <code>proxy.py</code></p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ python -m proxy"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">python -m proxy</span></pre></div></li></ul><p dir="auto">See <a href="#plugin-developer-and-contributor-guide">Plugin Developer and Contributor Guide</a>if you plan to work with <code>proxy.py</code> source code.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 from command line when starting the docker container. applications.</p><p dir="auto"><a href="https://github.com/abhinavsingh/proxy.py#user-content-shortlinkplugin"><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/abhinavsingh/proxy.py/develop/shortlink.gif" alt="Shortlink Plugin" data-animated-image="" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">Start <code>proxy.py</code> as:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ proxy \    --plugins proxy.plugin.ShortLinkPlugin"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">proxy \</span><span class="pl-c1">    --plugins proxy.plugin.ShortLinkPlugin</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">Now you can speed up your daily browsing experience by visiting yourfavorite website using single character domain names :). This worksacross all browsers.</p><p dir="auto">Following short links are enabled by default:</p><table><thead><tr><th align="center">Short Link</th><th align="center">Destination URL</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td align="center">a/</td><td align="center"><code>amazon.com</code></td></tr><tr><td align="center">i/</td><td align="center"><code>instagram.com</code></td></tr><tr><td align="center">l/</td><td align="center"><code>linkedin.com</code></td></tr><tr><td align="center">f/</td><td align="center"><code>facebook.com</code></td></tr><tr><td align="center">g/</td><td align="center"><code>google.com</code></td></tr><tr><td align="center">t/</td><td align="center"><code>twitter.com</code></td></tr><tr><td align="center">w/</td><td align="center"><code>web.whatsapp.com</code></td></tr><tr><td align="center">y/</td><td align="center"><code>youtube.com</code></td></tr><tr><td align="center">proxy/</td><td align="center"><code>localhost:8899</code></td></tr></tbody></table><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">ModifyPostDataPlugin</h3><a id="user-content-modifypostdataplugin" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: ModifyPostDataPlugin" 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Modifies POST request body before sending request to upstream server.</p><p dir="auto">Start <code>proxy.py</code> as:</p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="❯ proxy \    --plugins proxy.plugin.ModifyPostDataPlugin"><pre>❯ <span class="pl-s1">proxy \</span><span class="pl-c1">    --plugins proxy.plugin.ModifyPostDataPlugin</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">By default plugin replaces POST body content with hard-coded <code>b'{"key": "modified"}'</code>and enforced <code>Content-Type: application/json</code>.</p><p dir="auto">Verify the same using <code>curl -x localhost:8899 -d '{"key": "value"}' http://httpbin.org/post</code></p><div class="highlight highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="{  "args": {},  "data": "{\"key\": \"modified\"}",  "files": {},  "form": {},  "headers": {    "Accept": "*/*",    "Content-Length": "19",    "Content-Type": "application/json",    "Host": "httpbin.org",    "User-Agent": "curl/7.54.0"  },  "json": {    "key": "modified"  },  "origin": "1.2.3.4, 5.6.7.8",  "url": "https://httpbin.org/post"}"><pre><span class="pl-c1">{</span><span class="pl-c1">  "args": {},</span><span class="pl-c1">  "data": "{\"key\": \"modified\"}",</span><span class="pl-c1">  "files": {},</span><span class="pl-c1">  "form": {},</span><span class="pl-c1">  "headers": {</span><span class="pl-c1">    "Accept": "*/*",</span><span class="pl-c1">    "Content-Length": "19",</span><span class="pl-c1">    "Content-Type": "application/json",</span><span class="pl-c1">    "Host": "httpbin.org",</span><span class="pl-c1">    "User-Agent": "curl/7.54.0"</span><span class="pl-c1">  },</span><span class="pl-c1">  "json": {</span><span class="pl-c1">    "key": "modified"</span><span class="pl-c1">  },</span><span class="pl-c1">  "origin": "1.2.3.4, 5.6.7.8",</span><span class="pl-c1">  "url": "https://httpbin.org/post"</span><span class="pl-c1">}</span></pre></div><p dir="auto">Note following from the response above:</p><ol dir="auto"><li>POST data was modified <code>"data": "{\"key\": \"modified\"}"</code>.Original <code>curl</code> command data was <code>{"key": "value"}</code>.</li><li>Our <code>curl</code> command did not add any <code>Content-Type</code> header,but our plugin did add one <code>"Content-Type": "application/json"</code>.Same can also be verified by looking at <code>json</code> field in the output above:<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=""json": { "key": "modified"},"><pre class="notranslate"><code>"json": { "key": "modified"},</code></pre></div></li><li>Our plugin also added a <code>Content-Length</code> header to match lengthof modified body.</li></ol><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" highlight-text-shell-session notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="{"count": 2, "next": null, "previous": null, "results": [{"email": [redacted] ...< HTTP/1.1 404 NOT FOUND< Server: proxy.py v1.0.0< Connection: Close<* Closing connection 0"><pre class="notranslate"><code>... [redacted] ...< HTTP/1.1 404 NOT FOUND< Server: proxy.py v1.0.0< Connection: Close<* Closing connection 0</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">Above <code>404</code> response was returned from <code>proxy.py</code> web server.</p><p dir="auto">Verify the same by inspecting the logs for <code>proxy.py</code>.Along with the proxy request log, you must also see a http web server request log.</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="...
